1.segment: Abstract Importance : Prevalence of post-viral olfactory loss has increased dramatically due to the frequency and severity of olfactory dysfunction associated with infection by the SARS-CoV-2 virus .

2.segment: Objective : To determine the trajectory of COVID-19 olfactory loss over a six-month period .

3.segment: A key secondary objective is to assess predictive factors associated with the recovery of olfaction .

4.segment: Design : Longitudinal repeated-measures study that enrolled from May 5 ,

6.segment: with the last date of data collection on June 15 , 2021 .

7.segment: Setting : Barnes-Jewish HealthCare/Washington University School of Medicine facilities ( Saint Louis , Missouri , USA ) .

8.segment: Participants : Individuals who tested positive for SARS-CoV-2 by real-time polymerase chain reaction on nasopharyngeal swab and indicated olfactory loss on COVID-19 screening questionnaire .

9.segment: Individuals were excluded if they had previously diagnosed history of olfactory loss ,

10.segment: neurodegenerative disorders , less than 18 years of age ,

11.segment: admitted to hospital service , unable to read ,

13.segment: or lacked computer or internet access .

14.segment: Interventions/Exposures : Watch and wait for spontaneous recovery .

15.segment: Main Outcome ( s ) and Measure ( s ) : Participants completed olfactory assessments every 30 days for six months .

16.segment: Each assessment consisted of the University of Pennsylvania Smell Identification Test ( UPSIT ) ,

17.segment: an objective scratch-and-sniff test , and Clinical Global Impressions ( CGI ) ,

19.segment: Results : The mean age was 41 years old ( SD = 16 ) .

21.segment: At baseline assessment of objective olfaction ,

22.segment: 18 ( 36 % ) participants had anosmia or severe hyposmia .

23.segment: Subjective , complete recovery at six months was 81 % ( 95 % CI 74 % to 88 % ) .

24.segment: Likelihood of recovery was associated with age less than 50 years ( aHR = 8.1 ( 95 % CI 1.1 to 64.1 ) ) and mild olfactory loss at baseline ( UPSIT = 30-33 for males and 31-34 for females ) ( aHR 6.2 ( 95 % CI 1.2 to 33.0 ) ) .

25.segment: Conclusions and Relevance : The trajectory of olfactory recovery among adults with COVID-19 olfactory loss illustrated rapid recovery within 2-3 weeks of infection ,

26.segment: and by six months 81 % had recovered based on self-report .

27.segment: Age less than 50 years old and mild severity of olfactory loss at baseline were associated with increased likelihood of recovery of olfaction .

28.segment: These findings can be used to inform shared decision-making with patients .
